Chapter 18: The Six PÄramitÄs
SubhÅ«ti said:
World-Honored One!

As the Buddha previously said to make offerings to the six directions, the six directions are the six pÄramitÄs. Such a person will be able to increase wealth and longevity. What are the characteristics of such a person?
The Buddha said:
Good man!

If one is able to not be stingy with any wealth and property, always doing beneficial things for others, thinking of giving, joyfully practicing giving, giving whatever one has, regardless of the amount, when practicing giving, not giving rise to a sense of lightness towards one's body or wealth, giving purely without discriminating between those who uphold precepts and those who violate precepts;

Praising giving, seeing giving being practiced, rejoicing without jealousy, seeing those who ask, the mind is then delighted, rising to welcome and pay homage, offering a seat to sit, if the person in front asks or does not ask, then praising the fruit of giving;

Seeing those in fear, able to rescue and protect them, in times of famine, delighting in giving food and drink, although making these gifts, not for the sake of reward, not seeking repayment for kindness;
Not deceiving sentient beings, able to praise the merits and virtues of the Three Jewels, not using weights and measures mixed with other inferior things to deceive people;
Not delighting in the mind of greed for alcohol, gambling, and desire;
Always cultivating the virtues of shame and remorse, although extremely wealthy, the mind is not indulgent, practicing giving widely, not giving rise to arrogance:
Good man!
If one has these characteristics, one should know that this person will be able to make offerings and practice the perfection of giving.
Good man!

If there are people who can purify their body, speech, and mind, always cultivate a gentle mind, do not commit offenses, if they mistakenly do something wrong, they always feel ashamed and repent, believe that evil karma will result in bad consequences;
In the small virtues, they give rise to the thought of extreme seriousness, if they have done something wrong, they are terrified and regretful;

They never beat, scold, or harm sentient beings, speak first with a gentle mind, see sentient beings with a loving mind, know gratitude and repay kindness, their mind is not stingy, and they do not deceive sentient beings;

They seek wealth according to the Dharma, enjoy creating blessings and virtues, and always use their merits to transform others. Seeing those who are poor and suffering, they would take on their suffering for them;

They always cultivate a compassionate mind, pitying all, seeing those who do evil, they are able to stop and protect them, seeing those who do good, they praise their virtues and speak of the results, and with their physical strength, they go to assist them;
Their body is not independent, but they allow others to be independent;
Always cultivate a mind free from anger, and even if it arises for a moment, be aware and repent;
Speak truthfully and softly, and stay far away from divisive speech and meaningless speech.
Good man!
If one has these characteristics, know that this person can make offerings to the perfection of morality.
Good man!

If a person can purify the actions of body, speech, and mind, even if sentient beings do great evil to them, they will not give rise to a single thought of anger, and will never retaliate with evil. If the other comes to repent, they will immediately accept it;
When seeing sentient beings, their mind is always joyful. Seeing those who do evil, they give rise to a compassionate mind;
They praise the fruits of patience and rebuke anger, speaking of the fruits of anger as having much suffering and poison;
When cultivating giving and patience, they first extend it to their enemies;
They contemplate the five aggregates as a combination of many conditions. If they are combined, why give rise to anger?

deeply contemplating that anger is the cause and condition for receiving suffering in the future in immeasurable evil destinies, if anger arises for a moment, then shame, remorse, and a repentant mind arise;
seeing others' patience and excellence, one does not give rise to jealousy:
Good sons!
If one has these characteristics, one should know that this person is able to make offerings to the perfection of patience.
Good sons!

If there is a person who is able to not be lazy, not enjoy or crave the pleasures of sitting and lying down, as when exerting the power of great meritorious deeds and when attending to small matters, the mind is also like this;
in all activities, one must bring them to completion, when working, one does not consider hunger, thirst, cold, heat, time or non-time, and does not slight oneself;
before great matters are finished, one does not give rise to a regretful mind, when the work is completed, one rejoices in being able to accomplish it;
praising the fruits obtained by diligence - using wealth obtained according to the Dharma - seeing those who are wrongly diligent, explaining the evil fruits to them;
Well teaching sentient beings to cultivate diligence, not resting in the middle of what is done;
When cultivating wholesome dharmas, not following the words of others;
Good sons!
If one has these characteristics, one should know that this person is able to make offerings to the perfection of diligence.
Good sons!

If there are people who are able to purify body, speech, and mind, enjoy dwelling in seclusion, in caves, mountains, forests, or empty houses, do not enjoy noise and attachment to bedding, do not enjoy listening to worldly matters, do not enjoy greed, anger, or ignorance;
First speaking gentle words, always enjoying leaving the home life to teach and transform sentient beings;
Having afflictions that are light, mild, and thin, leaving evil thoughts and speculations;
Seeing enemies, cultivating kindness, enjoying speaking of definite retribution;
If the mind is agitated, giving rise to fear, shame, and regret;
Seeing those of wrong concentration, speaking of their faults, skillfully transforming sentient beings and placing them in right concentration;
Good sons!
Those who have these characteristics should be known as people who can make offerings to the perfection of meditation.
Good man!
If there are people who can purify body, speech, and mind, learn all worldly matters, not be greedy or attached to the mind of greed, anger, or delusion, not be crazy or confused;
Have compassion for sentient beings, be good at making offerings to parents, teachers, preceptors, elders, and those with virtue;
Cultivate non-negligence;
Speak softly first, do not deceive sentient beings, be able to distinguish and explain the wrong path, the right path, and the retribution of good and evil;
Always enjoy leaving the household life and practicing the path;
Be able to use worldly matters to teach sentient beings, see those whose learning surpasses oneself without giving rise to jealous thoughts, surpass others without giving rise to arrogance;
Do not worry when experiencing suffering, do not rejoice when experiencing happiness:
Good man!
Those who have these characteristics should be known as people who can make offerings to the perfection of wisdom.
Good man!
Each of the four directions has four things.
The four of the direction of giving are:
First,
taming sentient beings, second, being free from opposition, third, benefiting oneself, and fourth, benefiting others.
If a person is not stingy with wealth and does not discriminate between enemies and friends, or between the right and wrong time, this person can then tame sentient beings.
Because they do not begrudge wealth, they can practice giving. Therefore, they can be free from the evil of stinginess, which is called being free from opposition.

Wishing to give, giving at the right time, and rejoicing after giving without regret, therefore in the future one will receive the bliss of humans and gods up to the bliss of unsurpassed [enlightenment]. This is called benefiting oneself.
Being able to free others from the suffering of hunger and thirst is called benefiting others.
The four of the direction of precepts are:
First, adorning enlightenment, second, being free from opposition, third, benefiting oneself, and fourth, benefiting others.

Adorning enlightenment means that from the precepts of an upÄsaka to the precepts of a bodhisattva, one can become the root and foundation for the initial stage of anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi. This is called adorning.
Having received the precepts, one can further avoid evil precepts and lack of precepts. This is called avoiding opposition.
Having received and upheld the precepts, one attains the bliss of humans and gods up to the unsurpassed bliss. This is called benefiting oneself.
Having received the precepts, one bestows fearlessness upon all beings, causing them all to be free from suffering and attain peace. This is called benefiting others.
The four aspects of patience are:
First, adorning enlightenment; second, avoiding opposition; third, benefiting oneself; fourth, benefiting others.

Adorning enlightenment means that because of patience, one can cultivate goodness. Because of cultivating goodness, one attains the initial stage up to anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi. This is called adorning.
Having cultivated patience, one can avoid anger and evil. This is called avoiding opposition.
Because of the causes and conditions of patience, one attains the bliss of humans and gods up to unsurpassed bliss, this is called benefiting oneself.
Because of the causes and conditions of patience, people give rise to a joyful mind, a kind mind, and a disciplined mind, this is called benefiting others.
The four aspects of vigor are:
First, adorning enlightenment; second, leaving behind opposition; third, benefiting oneself; fourth, benefiting others.

As for adorning enlightenment, because of vigor one attains the cultivation of goodness, and because of cultivating good dharmas one attains the first ground up to unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment, this is called adorning.
When cultivating good dharmas, one leaves behind evil laziness, this is called leaving behind opposition.
Because of these good dharmas, one attains the bliss of humans and gods up to unsurpassed bliss, this is called benefiting oneself.
Teaching sentient beings to cultivate goodness and leave behind evil dharmas, this is called benefiting others.
The four aspects of meditation are:
First, adorning enlightenment; second, being free from opposition; third, benefiting oneself; fourth, benefiting others.
As for adorning enlightenment, by cultivating the power of such dhyÄna and concentration, one attains the first ground up to unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment. This is called adorning.
Because of this dhyÄna and concentration, one cultivates immeasurable goodness and is free from evil thoughts and speculations. This is called being free from opposition.
Because of cultivating the power of Å›amatha, one always delights in tranquility, attains human and heavenly bliss up to unsurpassed bliss. This is called benefiting oneself.
Cutting off the minds of greed, anger, and delusion of all sentient beings, this is called benefiting others.
The four aspects of wisdom are:
First, adorning enlightenment; second, being free from opposition; third, benefiting oneself; fourth, benefiting others.
Adorning enlightenment means that by cultivating wisdom, one attains the first ground up to supreme perfect enlightenment. This is called adorning.
Because of cultivating wisdom, one is able to distance oneself from ignorance and prevent afflictions from becoming rampant. This is called leaving behind opposition.
Eliminating the afflictions and the obstructions to wisdom is called benefiting oneself.
Teaching and transforming sentient beings to attain discipline is called benefiting others.
Good man!
Some say that apart from precepts there is no patience, and apart from wisdom there is no concentration. Therefore, it is said that there are four perfections.

If one is able to endure evil and not retaliate, that is called precepts;ğŸ”½If one cultivates concentration and the mind is not heedless, that is wisdom. Therefore, precepts are patience, and wisdom is concentration.
Apart from wisdom there is no concentration, and apart from concentration there is no wisdom. Therefore, wisdom is concentration, and concentration is wisdom.
Apart from precepts, there is no effort; apart from effort, there are no precepts. Therefore, precepts are effort, and effort is precepts.
Apart from giving, there is no effort; apart from effort, there is no giving. Therefore, giving is effort, and effort is giving.
Therefore, knowing that there are no six pÄramitÄs is not correct!
Why is it so?
Wisdom is the cause, and giving is the effect;ğŸ”½Effort is the cause, and upholding precepts is the effect;
SamÄdhi is the cause, and patience is the effect.
However, cause and effect cannot be the same. Therefore, there must be six pÄramitÄs.
If someone says 'precepts are patience, and patience is precepts,' this is not correct!
Why is it so?
Precepts are obtained from others, but patience is not like this;

There are those who do not take precepts but are able to endure evil, cultivate goodness for the sake of the multitude, endure countless sufferings, and for immeasurable lives substitute for all sentient beings in enduring great suffering and distress, without regret or retreat in their minds. Therefore, patience should exist apart from precepts.
Good man!
SamÄdhi is Å›amatha, and wisdom is vipaÅ›yanÄ.

Åšamatha is called being focused on one thing without disturbance, and vipaÅ›yanÄ is called being able to discriminate. Therefore, I explain in the twelve divisions of the canon that samÄdhi and wisdom are different. One should know that samÄdhi has the six pÄramitÄs.

The reason the TathÄgata first explains the pÄramitÄ of giving is to tame sentient beings.ğŸ”½When giving, one is free from greed. Therefore, the pÄramitÄ of morality is explained next.ğŸ”½When giving, one is able to endure the mind of letting go. Therefore, the pÄramitÄ of patience is explained next.
When giving, the mind delights and does not consider the time. Therefore, the pÄramitÄ of vigor is explained next.
When giving, the mind is single-minded, without any chaotic appearances, therefore, concentration pÄramitÄ is explained next.
When giving, it is not for the sake of experiencing the pleasures of birth and death, therefore, wisdom pÄramitÄ is explained next.
Good man!
What is called pÄramitÄ?

When giving, not seeking internal or external rewards, not observing fields of blessings or non-fields of blessings, giving all wealth, the mind not stingy or miserly, not choosing the time or occasion, therefore it is called the perfection of giving.
Even for minor offenses, though it may cost one's life, one still does not violate them, therefore it is called the perfection of precepts.
Even when evil people come and cut off one's body, one endures without anger, therefore it is called the perfection of forbearance.
For three months, in praise of the Buddha with a single verse, not stopping or resting, therefore it is called the perfection of vigor.
Fully attaining the vajra samÄdhi, therefore it is called the perfection of meditation.
Good man!
When they attain supreme, perfect enlightenment, they will be fully endowed with the accomplishment of the six perfections. Therefore, it is called the perfection of wisdom.
Good man!
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
First, those who are householders, and second, those who have left the household life.
Those who have left the household life can purify the six perfections, which is not difficult;
Those who are householders can purify them, which is difficult.
Why is it so?
Because householders are often entangled with many unfavorable conditions.
Chapter 19: Miscellaneous Chapter, UpÄsaka Precepts SÅ«tra, Miscellaneous Chapter, Chapter 19, Good Son said:
World-Honored One!
If bodhisattvas have already cultivated the six perfections, what kind of things can they do for sentient beings?
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas can pull out sentient beings who are drowning in the sea of suffering.
Good man!

If one is stingy with wealth, Dharma, and food, one should know that this person will receive the retribution of stupidity and poverty for immeasurable lifetimes. Therefore, when bodhisattvas practice the perfection of giving, they must benefit themselves and benefit others.
Good man!

If a person delights in giving, all enemies will give rise to thoughts of intimacy, and those who are not free will all attain freedom. Believing in the causes and effects of giving and believing in the causes and effects of precepts, this person will then attain the fruition of giving.
Good man!
Some people say:
'Giving is precisely the mind.
Why is it so?
Because the mind is the root of giving.'
This is not so!
Why is it so?
Giving is precisely the five aggregates.
Why is it so?
Because giving is complete through body, speech, and mind.

If giving is for one's own benefit, the benefit of others, or the benefit of both oneself and others, then it is complete with the five aggregates. Such giving can then adorn the path to enlightenment.
The result of giving is far removed from afflictions, and one becomes wealthy with abundant possessions.
The remaining results of giving are longevity, physical appearance, strength, happiness, and eloquence.
There are three kinds of results of giving:
Because of having superior wealth, one attains superior results.
Because of the superiority of the field, one attains superior results.
Because of the superiority of the giver, one attains superior results.

From the one heading towards the stream-enterer to the bodhisattva in the final stage, up to becoming a buddha, this is called the superior field. Because one gives to such a field, one attains superior results.
If the objects of giving are endowed with excellent color, fragrance, taste, and touch, this is called the superiority of the objects. Because one gives such objects, one attains superior results.
If the giver has pure faith, giving, morality, learning, and wisdom, then one attains superior results.
Good man!
The wise person's giving is of five kinds:
First, giving with utmost sincerity; second, giving with one's own hands; third, giving with faith; fourth, timely giving; fifth, giving things obtained lawfully.
Good man!
What fruits does giving with utmost sincerity bring?

If one gives with utmost sincerity, this person will obtain much wealth and treasures - gold, silver, lapis lazuli, carnelian, agate, pearls, coral, elephants, horses, oxen, sheep, fields, houses, and servants - and have many dependents.
Giving with utmost sincerity brings such fruits.
What fruits does giving with one's own hands bring?
Having given with one's own hands, the fruits and rewards obtained are as explained above;
having obtained them, one is able to use them. Giving with one's own hands brings such rewards.
What fruits does giving with faith bring?
Having given with faith, the fruits and rewards obtained are as explained above;
They are always loved and cherished by their parents, siblings, relatives, and all sentient beings. Those who give with faith receive such rewards.
What kind of fruits does one who gives at the right time obtain?
One who gives at the right time obtains the fruits and rewards as explained above;
They obtain the necessary things in a timely manner. One who gives at the right time also obtains such fruits.
What kind of fruits does one who gives wealth in accordance with the Dharma obtain?
One who gives wealth in accordance with the Dharma obtains the fruits and rewards as explained above;
After obtaining this wealth, it cannot be taken away by kings, thieves, water, or fire.
If one gives beautiful colors, because of this cause and condition, this person will obtain a subtle and excellent appearance;
If one gives fragrances, because of this, one's fame will spread far and wide;
If one gives flavors, because of this, many will enjoy seeing and hearing [this person], and after seeing and hearing, they will give rise to a mind of affection and respect;
If one gives pleasant textures, because of this, this person will obtain the most wonderful textures;
The recipient, having received it, will then be able to obtain longevity, complexion, strength, peace, and eloquence.
Good man!
Some people say that giving to stupas and images does not obtain longevity, complexion, strength, peace, and eloquence, because there is no recipient. This is not so!
Why is it so?
Because there is faith. The donor practices giving with faith, and therefore should obtain such five rewards.
Good man!
It is like a bhiká¹£u cultivating a mind of loving-kindness. Such a mind of loving-kindness truly has no recipient, yet he still obtains immeasurable rewards;
Giving to stupas and images should also be like this, obtaining the five rewards.
Good man!
It is like a person planting grain, which will never produce gourds;

Giving to stupas and images is also like this. Because of the field of blessings, one obtains various rewards. Therefore, I say that the field obtains the reward, the object obtains the reward, and the master obtains the reward.
Good man!
There are two kinds of giving:
First, the giving of Dharma; second, the giving of material things.
The giving of Dharma brings rewards of both material wealth and Dharma, while the giving of material things only brings rewards of material wealth.
Bodhisattvas practice these two kinds of giving for two purposes:
First, to cause sentient beings to be free from suffering and distress; second, to cause sentient beings to attain mental discipline.
Good man!
There are also three kinds of giving:
First, the giving of Dharma; second, the giving of fearlessness; third, the giving of material things.
The giving of Dharma refers to teaching others to receive precepts, leave the household life, cultivate the path, and perform the fourfold karman;
To destroy wrong views, expound the correct Dharma, be able to distinguish what is real and what is not, proclaim the four inverted views and non-negligence - this is called the giving of Dharma.

If there are sentient beings who are afraid of kings, lions, tigers, wolves, water, fire, or robbers, the Bodhisattva, upon seeing them, is able to rescue and deliver them, which is called the giving of fearlessness.

As for oneself, regarding wealth and treasures, one breaks through stinginess and is not miserly. Whether good or bad, many or few, cattle, sheep, elephants, horses, houses, bedding, trees, springs, wells, male and female servants, water buffaloes, camels, donkeys, carriages, palanquins, jars, basins, cauldrons, ropes, sitting mats, copper, iron, earthenware vessels, clothing, necklaces, lamps, incense, flowers, fans, umbrellas, hats, shoes, tables, staffs, ropes, plows, sickles, axes, chisels, grass, trees, water, and stones, one gives according to the wishes of the seeker, according to their needs, which is called the giving of wealth.
If one builds a monastery or a separate room and gives it to renunciant practitioners, except for elephants and horses, as above.
Good man!
There are four burdens in giving:
First, a stingy mind; second, not practicing giving; third, despising small things; fourth, seeking worldly rewards.
These four burdens can be destroyed by two dharmas:
First, cultivating non-self; second, cultivating impermanence.
Good man!
If one wishes to happily give, one should break five things:

First, an angry mind; second, a stingy mind; third, a jealous mind; fourth, cherishing one's life; fifth, not believing in cause and effect.ğŸ”½Having broken these five things, one always happily gives.
One who happily gives obtains five things:

First, they will never be far from all sages; second, all beings will enjoy seeing and hearing them; third, when entering the great assembly, they will not be afraid; fourth, they will obtain a good reputation; fifth, they will adorn enlightenment.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas are called givers of everything. What is meant by giving everything?
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas seek things in accordance with the Dharma and give them away, called giving everything;
Always giving with a pure mind to the recipient, called giving everything;
Being able to give even with few things, called giving everything;
Giving away cherished things, breaking through stinginess and being able to let go, called giving everything;
Giving without seeking reward, called giving everything;
When giving, not observing the field of blessings or not, called giving everything;
Giving equally to enemies and friends, called giving everything.

Bodhisattvas giving wealth has two kinds - one is sentient beings, the other is non-sentient beings - within these two, they are not at all stingy even with their own bodies, called giving everything;
Bodhisattvas giving by means of a compassionate mind, called giving everything;
wanting to give, giving at the time of giving, and not regretting after giving, called giving everything.

Sometimes even if it is an impure thing given, it is in order to cause the person in front to give rise to a joyful mind, alcohol, poison, knives, staffs, shackles, and other such things, whether one has sovereignty or does not have sovereignty, one should never give them;
Do not give impure food and medicine to sick people;
Do not rob others of even a single coin to give in charity.
When a bodhisattva gives, although they have sovereignty, they should never scold or beat their servants and slaves, causing them to give rise to anger and suffering.
Give wealth according to the Dharma, not seeking present or future rewards.
After giving, always contemplate the faults of afflictions and deeply contemplate the subtle merits of nirvana, seeking nothing else except for enlightenment.
When giving to the poor, arouse a compassionate mind;
When giving to those with merit, give rise to a joyful and respectful mind;
When giving to friends, do not give rise to a mind of abandonment.
If you see a beggar, then know what they need and provide it accordingly, without letting them speak.
Why is this?
By giving without waiting to be asked, one attains immeasurable fruits.
Good man!

There are three types of benefactors, namely inferior, middling, and superior.ğŸ”½Not believing in the fruits of karma, deeply attached to stinginess, fearing wealth will be exhausted, seeing those who come to beg gives rise to thoughts of anger and obstruction, this is called inferior.
Although believing in the fruits of karma, stinginess arises regarding wealth, fearing it will be depleted, seeing those who come to beg gives rise to a mind of letting go, this is called middling.

Deeply believing in the fruits of karma, they do not give rise to stinginess towards wealth and possessions. Regarding all wealth and possessions as impermanent, they see those who come seeking as either joyful when given or troubled when not given. They use their own bodies and possessions to give to them, which is called the highest.
There is also a lower type who, when they see someone come seeking, turns their face away and does not look at them, verbally abusing and insulting them.
There is also a middling type who, although they do give, does so with contempt and disrespect.
There is also a higher type who, without being asked, gives with a respectful mind.ğŸ”½There is also a lower type who gives for the sake of present rewards;
there is also a middling type who gives for the sake of future rewards;
there is also a higher type who gives out of compassion.
There is also a lower type who gives in order to repay kindness;
there is also a middling type who gives for the sake of karma;
there is also a higher type who gives as a Dharma treasure.ğŸ”½There is also a lower type who gives out of fear of the superior;
there is also a middling type who gives because they are equal to themselves;
There is also a higher type who do not discriminate between enemies and friends.
Moreover, the lower type says they have no wealth when they have some;ğŸ”½the middling type says they have little when they have much;
the higher type gives more than is asked for.
The giver who has no wealth is also of three types:
The lowest person, when seeing a beggar, has an evil mind and scolds them;
the middling person, when seeing a beggar, simply says they have nothing;
the superior person, when seeing a beggar, feels ashamed of having nothing and gives rise to sorrowful thoughts.
Good man!
Moreover, the lower type is always scolded by sages and worthies;
the middling type is always pitied by sages and worthies;
the superior type, when seen by sages and worthies, gives rise to joy in their minds.
Good man!

The wise person practices giving for the benefit of self and others, knowing that wealth and possessions are impermanent, in order to bring joy to sentient beings, out of compassion, to destroy stinginess, not seeking future rewards, and in order to adorn the path to enlightenment.

Therefore, the bodhisattva, having given everything, does not give rise to regret, does not worry about the depletion of wealth, does not belittle wealth, does not belittle his own body, does not consider the time, does not consider the supplicant, but always thinks of the beggar as if hungry, thinking of food.

He becomes close to good friends, consults and receives the right teachings, and when he sees a supplicant, his mind gives rise to joy, as if a house on fire were to get out its wealth, rejoicing and praising, speaking of the many faults of wealth.
After giving, he gives rise to joy, as if entrusting to a good person;
He further tells the beggar:
You are now truly the cause of my merit!
I am now far removed from stingy and greedy thoughts, all due to the conditions of your coming to beg.
then one should give rise to a mind of affection towards the petitioner.
After having given, one should further teach the petitioner to protect in accordance with the Dharma, and diligently make offerings to the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha treasures.

In this way, the bodhisattva, delighting in practicing giving, will then be able to distance oneself from all forms of heedlessness. Even if one gives one's body to a petitioner, one should not give rise to a single thought of an evil mind. Because of this, one will further increase one's compassion, sympathy, joy, and equanimity.

One should not look down on the recipient, nor should one be self-important. One should rejoice in having wealth that satisfies the intentions of the petitioner, and increase one's faith, without doubting the fruits of one's actions.
Good man!
If one is able to contemplate wealth as having the characteristic of impermanence, and to regard all sentient beings as one's only child, then such a person will be able to give to a petitioner.
Good man!
Such a person will not be moved by the fetters of stinginess, just as Mount Sumeru cannot be moved by the wind.
Such a person will be able to serve as a refuge for sentient beings. Such a person will be able to perfect the perfection of giving.
Good man!
The wise person, for four reasons, delights in practicing giving:

First, giving can break through afflictions; second, giving can give rise to various vows; third, giving can bring about the experience of bliss; fourth, giving can bring about the accumulation of wealth and treasures.
Good man!
The mind of non-greed is called giving.
What is non-greed?
Giving is the action, the object is the deed. The complete giving of the means of action and deed is called non-greed.
As for breaking through afflictions due to giving, having already practiced giving, one breaks through stinginess, greed, jealousy, anger, and ignorance.
How does giving give rise to various vows?
Having given in this way, one can give rise to various good and evil vows. Due to good and evil vows, one obtains good and evil fruits.
Why is it so?
It is because of the power of vows.
How does giving bring about the experience of bliss?
Because of this giving, one experiences the bliss of humans and gods up to the bliss of unsurpassed [nirvana].
How does giving lead to abundant wealth and treasures?
Because of this giving, one obtains gold, silver, and even animals as desired.
Good man!
If a person delights in giving, this person will destroy the five evil and harmful dharmas:
First, wrong views; second, lack of faith; third, negligence; fourth, stinginess; fifth, anger and obstruction.
Having separated from these evils, the mind gives rise to joy. Because of joy, one ultimately attains true liberation.
This person obtains four kinds of karmic rewards in the present:

First, everyone delights in seeing [him], even his enemies; second, his good reputation spreads in all four directions; third, when entering a great assembly, his mind is free from fear; fourth, all good people delight in coming to associate with him.
Good man!
After practicing giving, the mind is free from regret.
If this person falls into hell due to guest-dust afflictions, although in an evil place, they are not hungry or thirsty. By this cause and condition, they are free from two kinds of suffering:
first, the suffering of iron pellets, second, the suffering of iron liquid.
If they have the body of an animal, what is needed is easily obtained, without lack or shortage.
If they have the body of a hungry ghost, they do not experience hunger or thirst, and always get to be full.
If they attain a human body, their lifespan, appearance, strength, peace and happiness, eloquence, faith, precepts, giving, learning, and wisdom surpass everyone else;
although in an evil world, they do not do evil things, when evil dharmas arise, they never follow and accept them;
in places of fear, they do not give rise to fear.
If they attain a heavenly body, ten things are superior.
Good man!
A wise person, for two reasons, is able to practice giving:
first, to subdue their own mind, second, to destroy the hateful and angry mind.
For this reason, the TathÄgata is called the unsurpassed honored one.
Good man!

The wise, after giving, do not seek the loved one's thoughts, do not seek fame, do not seek to avoid fear, do not seek good people to come and see, do not seek to be close, and do not seek the rewards of heaven and humans;
They contemplate two things:
First, using impermanent wealth to exchange for permanent wealth, second, never following the mind of stinginess.
Why is it so?
If I die, this wealth will not follow me, therefore I should give with my own hands. I should not now follow loss and give rise to distress, I should follow giving and give rise to joy.
Good man!
The giver should first test his mind by giving external things;
Knowing the mind is subdued, next give internal things.
Because of these two kinds of giving, one attains two dharmas:
First, permanently leaving all existences, second, attaining correct liberation.
Good son!
It is like a person traveling far, carrying a heavy burden, tired and exhausted, putting it down and feeling at ease;
When a person practicing giving sees a beggar, giving away wealth and feeling joy in the mind, it is also like this.
Good son!
The wise always contemplate like this:
'If you want to make this wealth follow you to the next world, nothing is better than giving.'
They should also deeply contemplate the suffering of poverty and the happiness of wealth and nobility. Therefore, they always delight in practicing giving with a focused mind.
Good son!
If a person has wealth but tells a beggar they have none or are busy when they see a beggar,
Know that this person has already said that they will be poor and lacking in virtue in their next life. Such a person is called negligent.
Good son!
A person without wealth saying they have none is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
All people have water and grass. Even if one is the ruler of a country, one may not be able to give them away. Even if one is poor, one may not be able to give them away.
Why is this?
Even a poor person has a share of food. After eating, they wash the utensils and discard the leftover food. Giving this to those who can eat it also brings merit.
If one gives a bit of flour to ants, one will also obtain immeasurable meritorious rewards.
Who among the extremely poor in the world would not have this bit of flour?
Who is there whose life would not be sustained by eating three handfuls of flour a day?
Therefore, all people should give half of their food to beggars.
Good man!
Who among the extremely poor are there who are naked and have no clothes?
If they have clothes, how could they not have a single thread to give to others to mend their wounds, or a finger's worth of wealth to make a lamp wick?
Good man!
Who among the people of the world are there who are poor and bodiless?

If one has a body, seeing others making merit, one should go and assist them, rejoicing without weariness. One is also called a donor and also obtains merit. Sometimes there are those who have a share, who are equal, or who are superior.
For this reason, when I accept King Prasenajit's food, I also make a wish that the merit obtained by the king and the poor is the same, without distinction.
Good man!

It is like a person buying incense - anointing incense, powdered incense, scattered incense, and burning incense - these four kinds of incense, if someone touches it, buys it, or measures it, they all smell the same, without difference, and these incenses do not lose even a hair's breadth.
The virtue of cultivating giving is also like this:

whether much or little, coarse or fine, if one rejoices in the mind and goes to assist with the body, or if one sees or hears from afar and gives rise to joy in the mind, because the mind is the same, the obtained retribution is without distinction.
Good man!
If one has no wealth and does not rejoice in seeing others give, has doubts about the field of merit, this is called poverty;
If one has abundant wealth, is free and unhindered, has a good field of merit, but lacks inner faith and is unable to make offerings, this is also called poverty.
Therefore, the wise, according to their means, give according to their ability. Apart from giving, there is no way to attain the bliss of humans and gods up to the unsurpassed bliss.
Therefore, I say in the sutras:
'The wise should consider that if they eat one mouthful themselves, they will live, but if they give it to others, they will die. They should still give it away, let alone more.'
Good man!
The wise should consider that wealth is impermanent. Because it is impermanent, it is lost, destroyed, and wasted in immeasurable lives without any benefit;
Although it is impermanent, it can create immeasurable benefits. Why be stingy and not give in charity?

The wise one further observes the world, if there are those who uphold precepts and have much learning, by the power of the causes and conditions of upholding precepts and much learning, they may even attain the fruit of arhatship;

although attaining this fruit, they are unable to completely cut off the suffering of hunger and thirst, etc. - if arhats have difficulty obtaining dwellings, clothing, food and drink, bedding, and medicine, it is all due to the causes and conditions of not giving in past lives - if those who break the precepts happily practice giving, although such a person may fall into the realm of hungry ghosts or animals, they will always be full and have nothing lacking.
Good man!
Apart from giving, one cannot obtain two fruits:
first, self-mastery, second, liberation.
If those who uphold precepts are reborn in the heavens, due to not cultivating giving, they do not obtain the best food and exquisite ornaments.
If a person wishes to seek worldly happiness and the unsurpassed happiness, they should delight in giving.

The wise should contemplate that birth and death are endless, and so is the enjoyment of pleasure. Therefore, one should practice giving in order to end birth and death, not seeking to enjoy pleasure. One should also contemplate:

Although one may be wealthy and enjoy immeasurable pleasure on the four continents, one is still not content. Therefore, I should practice giving for the sake of supreme pleasure, not for the sake of humans or gods.
Why is this?
Because they are impermanent and have an end.
Good man!
If someone says:
The donor, the recipient, and the one who enjoys the pleasure are all the five aggregates. Such five aggregates are impermanent. If one gives away the five aggregates, who will enjoy them there?
Although there is no recipient, the good fruits do not perish. Therefore, there is no donor or recipient.
One should counter-question: Is there giving and receiving or not?
If they say 'giving is giving, and the recipient is me,' one should say to them, 'I am also like this. Giving is giving, and I am the five aggregates.'
If they say 'giving to the aggregates, this place is impermanent, who receives there?'ğŸ”½Listen carefully!
Listen carefully!
I will explain it for you.
Are seeds permanent?
Are they impermanent?
If you say they are permanent, how can the seed perish and give rise to a sprout?
If you see this fault and say they are impermanent, you should be told, 'If they are impermanent, how can the seed, manure, water, soil, and other efforts cause the sprout to grow?'
If you say 'although the seed is impermanent, because of the work, the sprout fruit is obtained,' you should say the five aggregates are also like this.
If you say 'the sprout already exists in the seed, and human effort, water, and manure are the causes for its manifestation,' this is not correct!
Why is it so?
The objects cognized by the illuminating cause do not increase or decrease. Many remain many, few remain few.
But now water, manure, and sprouts increase and grow. Therefore, they did not exist before but exist now.
If you say, 'The illuminating cause is of two kinds:
One is many, the other is few.
Many are seen as large, few are seen as small;
Just like a burning lamp, with much light seen as large, with little light seen as small,' this is not so.
Why is it so?
Just like a single kind, with much water and manure, it cannot simultaneously and in one day grow to the size of a person or beyond a person.

If you say, 'Although the illuminating cause is of two kinds, it must wait for the right time. When objects are few, they are few. When objects are many, they are many. Therefore, I say the illuminating cause does not increase,' this is not so!
Why is it so?
Your teaching is that time is always so. Therefore, you should not speak like this.
Good man!
Although the sprout is different and the fruit is different, the difference is produced by the same cause, and the similarity is not cut off. The five aggregates are also like this.
Good man!

Just as the sprout increases due to the power of the seed, the stem increases due to the power of the sprout, the leaf increases due to the power of the stem, the flower increases due to the power of the leaf, and the fruit increases due to the power of the flower;
The five aggregates of one path increase the five aggregates of the five paths in the same way.
If you say that in this way, the doer is different and the experiencer is different, this meaning belongs to you, not to what I have said.
Why is it so?
In your teachings, the doer is the self, and the experiencer is the body, yet you do not say that the doer is different and the experiencer is different;

The one who accepts the precept against killing is the self. For this reason, the body obtains wonderful form. Therefore, in your teachings, the experiencer has no cause, and the doer has no result. There is such a fault.
If you say, The self acts and the body experiences. I am also like this. This one acts and that one experiences....ğŸ”½...

You should further ask, 'Are your body and self different? Your body eats food, wears clothes and ornaments, and because of eating fine food, you obtain good complexion and strength, while because of eating poor food, you obtain poor complexion and strength. If these good and bad colors belong to causes and conditions, what do I obtain?'
If he says, 'I obtain sorrow and joy,' how is it not the case that something done by one is experienced by another?
For example, if a person takes ghee to gain strength, after a long time of taking it, his body obtains great strength and excellent complexion;
if another person is emaciated, seeing this, he becomes joyful. Does this person immediately obtain great complexion and strength?
If he says he does not obtain it, I am also like this:
how can I obtain what is done by the body?
Why is it so?
Because it is not similar.
My teaching is not like this: the aggregates do their own experiencing, similar and uninterrupted.
Good son!
If you say that the five aggregates are impermanent, and that this does not reach the other to receive retribution, this is not so!
Why is it so?
In my Dharma, there is that which is created and received immediately, there is that which is created differently and received differently, and there is that which is not created and not received.
That which is created and received immediately is that which is created by the aggregates and received by the aggregates;
That which is created differently and received differently is that which is created by humans and received by gods;
That which is not created and not received is that which arises from the combination of the causes and conditions of karma, originally without self-nature, how can there be creation and reception?
If your intention is to say that creation is different from reception, how can you also say that the continuity is not cut off?
This is not so!
Why is it so?

It is like placing poison in milk, when it reaches the stage of ghee it can still kill people. The milk is different, and the ghee is also different. Although there are differences, they arise in sequence, and the similarity is not cut off, so it can kill people;

The five aggregates are also like this. Although they have differences and arise in sequence, they are similar and uninterrupted. Therefore, it can be said that 'another creates and another experiences, one creates and one experiences, or there is no creating and no experiencing.'
If one is apart from the five aggregates, there is no self or what belongs to the self.
All sentient beings are covered by inverted thoughts, and some say that form is the self, up to consciousness is the self;
Some say that form is the self, and the remaining four aggregates belong to the self, up to consciousness is also like this.
If there is a saying that apart from the five aggregates there is a separate self, this is not the case.
Why is it so?
In our Buddhist teachings, form is not the self.
Why is it so?
Because it is impermanent, uncreated, and not autonomous, therefore the four aggregates are not called what belongs to the self;
Up to consciousness is also like this.
The combination of various conditions gives rise to different dharmas, which is called creation, but there is truly no other creation;
The combination of various conditions gives rise to a different dharma, which is called the receiver, but there is actually no different receiving.
Therefore, it is called 'no action, no receiving.'
If your idea is that the doer and the receiver are different, why does this person perform the action but not that person receive it?
Do they both have the five aggregates?
This reasoning is not correct!
Why is it so?
There are two kinds of differences:
one is difference in body, and the other is difference in name.
One is 'attained by the Buddha,' and the other is 'attained by the gods.'
'Attained by the Buddha' and 'attained by the gods' have different bodies and names. For this reason, body and mouth should be different;
since body and mouth are different, the creation of karma is also different;

since the creation of karma is different, lifespan, appearance, strength, peace, and eloquence are also different. Therefore, one cannot perform actions attained by the Buddha and receive their fruits attained by the gods.
Although both have the five aggregates, form and name are the same, but feeling, perception, and mental formations are different.
Why is this?
The Buddha experiences pleasure, while the gods experience suffering. The Buddha gives rise to craving, while the gods give rise to anger. Therefore, they cannot be said to be similar.
Although form and name are the same, in reality there are differences. Sometimes the Buddha experiences white color, while the gods experience black color.
If the same name is taken to mean the same thing, then when one person is born, all should be born, and when one person dies, all should die.
If you do not want to accept this meaning, then one cannot say that one experiences the results of actions done by another.
If you think that you also experience the results of actions done by another, and I am the same in experiencing the results of actions done by another,
if one experiences the results of actions done by another, then you should have the same fault as me. Why do you not see your own fault and instead blame me? This is not reasonable.
Why is this?
There are two kinds of differences:
First, arising in sequence and also ceasing in sequence; second, arising in sequence but not ceasing in sequence.

Because the arising is different, the ceasing is also different. Therefore, I say 'different actions lead to different experiences, and this action leads to this experience.' It is not the same as your error.
It is like a person who wants to burn a village. He puts a grain of fire into dry grass. Because of the sequential arising of causes and conditions, it can burn a hundred li to two hundred li.
The village chief finds out and immediately asks him:
'You evil person, for what reason did you burn this big village?'
That person replies:
'It is really not me who burned it.
Why is it so?
The fire I set has already been extinguished, and the place burned is only a handful of grass.
I will now return to you two handfuls. As for the rest, I should not repay you.'
At that time, the village chief says again:
'Foolish man!
Because of your small fire, it gradually produced fire, burning up to a hundred miles and even two hundred miles.
The fault lies with you, so why should you not repay it?'
Although they know that the fire is different in production and different in burning, the continuity is not cut off, so they incur the offense.
The five aggregates of good and evil are also like this:
Although the aggregates at the time of receiving retribution are said not to be produced, they are born in continuity with the preceding ones, and therefore they receive retribution.

It is like a person who makes a bet with another, holding a torch and traveling far, to a hundred miles away. If he does not arrive, he will lose the bet; if he does arrive, the other person will pay him.
The person holding the torch arrives at a hundred miles and immediately demands payment. The other person says:
'The torch you held has already gone out after you took a step, so why do you demand payment from me here?'
The person holding the torch says:
'Although that fire has gone out, it has produced a continuity that has come here.'
In this way, the statements of the two people both make sense.
Why is this?
This meaning is both the same and different, therefore both people are without fault.
If someone says 'the five aggregates are also like this, the doer and the receiver are the same, and the doer and the receiver are different,' both are without fault.

It is like this, the two banks and the middle current are collectively called the Ganges River. In the summer the two banks are very far apart, in the autumn the two banks are then close together, there is no constant fixed appearance, sometimes large, sometimes small, although it increases and decreases, people all call it a river.
Some say 'this is not a river,' the wise also say there is sameness and difference;
the five aggregates are also like this, the wise also say the doer and the receiver are the same, and the doer and the receiver are different.'
If your idea is 'the two banks are earth, the middle current is water, and the river god is the river,' this meaning is not so!
Why is it so?

If the spirit is the river, why is it also said that the river is clear or turbid, has this shore, that shore, and a middle current with varying depths, reaches the great ocean, and is either fordable or impassable?
It is like a tree, where a spirit resides. If there is no tree, where would the spirit dwell?
The river and the spirit should also be like this.
Therefore, this shore, that shore, and the middle current, in sequence and without interruption, are collectively called a river.
Therefore, it can be said that it is the same and different. The five aggregates are also like this.

It is like a person who insults and humiliates a noble person. Because of the evil words, his feet are shackled. These feet are actually without the crime of evil speech, yet they are shackled. Therefore, one cannot definitively say 'one who commits an action experiences the result' or 'one who does not commit an action does not experience the result.' Only a wise person can say 'one who commits an action experiences the result' or 'one who does not commit an action does not experience the result.'
It is like a vessel, oil, wick, fire, and a person tending to it - when these many conditions come together, it is called the light of a lamp.
If you think that the light of the lamp increases and decreases, this is not so!
Why is it so?
Because it is extinguished, it does not increase; because it comes, it does not decrease. Because it arises in sequence, it is said that the lamp increases and decreases.
If you think that the lamp is impermanent, but the oil is permanent, and that when there is more oil, there is more light, and when there is less oil, there is less light, this is not so!
Why is it so?
Because the oil is impermanent, it will be exhausted and burned.
If it were permanent, it should remain for two moments;
if it remained for two moments, who could burn it all up?

Therefore, a wise person also says that the light of the lamp is different, and so are the five aggregates. The light is the six sense bases, and the oil is karma. Due to the causes and conditions of oily karma, the five aggregates have increase and decrease, have that and have this.

It is like someone saying the words of Adiya, which Adiya long ago has passed away and is not in the present. Worldly people transmit them in succession, and they are not extinguished, so they are called the words of Adiya.
The wise also say these are the words of Adiya, and not the words of Adiya. Although they are both right and wrong, they do not lose the principle.
The five aggregates are also like this:
It can be said that the doer experiences the results, or that the doer is different from the one who experiences the results.
There was a very wealthy man whose family line was cut off, and he died. His property should have been confiscated by the government.
Someone said:
'This property should belong to me.'
The government officials said:
'How can this property be owned by someone else when it was created by someone else?'
This person said again:
'I am the seventh-generation descendant of the deceased, and the line has not been cut off. How can this property not belong to me?'
The government officials then said:
'It is just as you have said.
' The wise say that the five aggregates are also like this, that the doer creates and the receiver experiences, and that the doer and the receiver are different.

If you think that the five aggregates create karma, complete it, and then pass away, and that while this body remains, the karma has no basis, and if karma has no basis, then it is no karma, and after abandoning this body, how can it receive retribution?
This is not so.
Why is it so?
All past karma awaits the body and time.
It is like a tangerine seed that grows from a tangerine, and becomes sour from being sweet.

A person plants this seed for the sake of tangerines, and this seed, root, stem, leaf, flower, and growing fruit are all not sour. When the time comes for the fruit to ripen, the sour taste then arises.
In this way, the sour taste is not originally non-existent, and now it exists, nor is it without conditions, but is the cause and condition of the past original fruit;
The karma of body, speech, and mind is also like this.
If it is asked where does this karma reside, this karma resides in the past, waiting for the time and the vessel to receive the karmic retribution.
Just as when a person takes medicine, even though the medicine is digested and disappears, when the time comes, it produces good strength and good complexion;
The karma of body, speech, and mind is also like this. Even though it has already passed away, when the time comes, one will receive it.
It is like a child's initial learning. Even though it disappears moment by moment and has no place to abide, even after a hundred years, it is not lost;
The past karma is also like this. Even though it has no place to abide, when the time comes, one will naturally receive it.
Therefore, it is said:
The aggregates do not create the aggregates and receive them, nor can they be received by what is not the aggregates.
If one can clearly penetrate this matter, then one will be able to attain the unsurpassed fruit.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
